title: Bugfix for spot controller
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1500 didn't consider the case when `cloud` is not specified by users and a bug will be triggered during recovery.
This PR fixes it by checking the `launched_resources` in `handle` to make sure cloud is not `None`.

====

Details:

The reason why I introduce `self.launched_resources` in `StrategyExecutor` is because the `handle` returns by
```
(cluster_status,
             handle) = backend_utils.refresh_cluster_status_handle(
                 self._cluster_name, force_refresh=True)
```
in `controller.py` could be `None` if the spot VM is preempted. I thought adding `self.launched_resources` under `StrategyExecutor` would be a better design.
Please let me know if there's a better alternative.

<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of Github CI; the below are additional tests. -->

title: Add note on how to switch GCP project
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

Add a note to installation doc for GCP users (https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1535, https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1193) to switch projects.

In fact, our code might misunderstood GCP config semantic. The below config file `~/.config/gcloud/configurations/config_default` may not be the current GCP project in use.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/b5e0dabe42c58be22d75ec3eb021ba383636a61b/sky/clouds/gcp.py#L22
The one in use should be indicated in `~/.config/gcloud/active_config`. But since our code uploads all the configs under `/configurations`, everything works okay.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/b5e0dabe42c58be22d75ec3eb021ba383636a61b/sky/clouds/gcp.py#L32-L34
Still, we probably want to rename those constant names to avoid confusion. cc @Michaelvll

title: UX: print "to fix" suggestions for rsync related errors
body:
Currently rsync related errors (e.g., transient network issues; we should look for repros) are not helpful because they don't display "how to fix" suggestions. 

In general, we should strive for including in each error message some "to fix" hints.

Examples -- we should audit all these places:
```
...
Failed to run command before rsync <my bucket> -> ~/sky_workdir.

...
Failed to rsync up: <script> -> ~/.sky/spot_tasks/<yaml>
```

In the above, a simple hint to add could be, "Ensure network is stable, then retry the command/API."

----

Orthoghnoally -- We may also want to add retries for these rsync's.

Here's an example of running the `test_logs` smoke test and encountering likely transient rsync errors:

title: UX: users may call `cancel` on spot controller
body:
When users call
```
sky cancel <spot controller> 1
```
We currently show
```
ValueError: Cluster 'sky-spot-controller-1234' is reserved for spot controller. Cancelling jobs is not allowed.
```
We should additionally show something like, 
```
...
Use `sky spot cancel <spot job id>` to cancel spot jobs.
```

title: UX: `sky cancel` usage hints should be friendlier
body:
Users tended to type `sky cancel <job id>` when they only started playing with one cluster.

This would show
```
click.exceptions.UsageError: sky cancel requires either a job id (see `sky queue 1 -s`) or the --all flag.
```

We should instead show something like
```
... Use `sky cancel <cluster name> <job id>` or `sky cancel <cluster name> --all`. Job IDs can be looked up by `sky queue`.
```

W 12-17 14:46:04 common_utils.py:216] Caught <HttpError 403 when requesting https://compute.googleapis.com/compute/v1/projects/wrong-project-name?alt=json returned "Required 'compute.projects.get' permission for 'projects/wrong-project-name'". title: Fix sky start for AMI without conda
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

Fixes https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1517 and add one smoke test to cover this case in which an AMI without conda is used.
The bug can be reproduced by the following yaml.
```
resources:
  cloud: aws
  instance_type: g4dn.xlarge
  region: us-west-2
  image_id: ami-0fe5af21074ad2a10  # Deep learning AMI with CUDA 11.6

setup: |
  echo 

run: |
  nvidia-smi
```

```
> sky launch -c test test.yaml
> sky stop test
> sky start test
...
Command 'ray' not found, did you mean:
```

This AMI doesn't contain conda and we install conda during `sky launch`. But later `sky start` detects conda is installed and set `conda config --set auto_activate_base false` which disables conda again. I believe it should not be needed because we still use conda python even with this command + pre-installed conda AMI.
Using master to do `sky launch` an AWS VM:
```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-90-40:~$ which python
/opt/conda/bin/python
ubuntu@ip-172-31-90-40:~$ which pip3
/opt/conda/bin/pip3
```
(note that `gcp-ray.yml.j2` and `azure-ray.yml.j2` also don't have `conda config --set auto_activate_base false`)
If we confirm this config command is not needed. simply remove it can fix the issue.

LOC indicated here: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/master/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L2106

title: [Onprem] `run.log` not appearing when local computer and onprem cluster are the same
body:
When the Ray job is submitted, the python command is run via a bash script defined here:
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/master/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2337

On the local computer, the bash script is deleted after uploaded to the remote cluster. However, if the local computer and the remote cluster are the same, the script is deleted, which means the Ray job cannot be run.

title: [Provisioner] Generate valid cluster names when username has invalid characters
body:
Closes #1161.

We now clean up the username (used as suffix in the cluster name) by:

1. Making all characters lowercase
2. Removing any non-alphanumeric characters (excluding hyphens)
3. Removing any numbers and/or hyphens at the start of the username.
4. Removing any hyphens at the end of the username

e.g. `1SkY-PiLot2-` becomes `sky-pilot2` when it is used for generating cluster name.

## Tested:

Manual tests by overriding the username read by getpass.getuser():
- [x] `LOGNAME=RomilB sky launch` - uppercase characters
- [x] `LOGNAME=romil-b sky launch` - hypen
- [x] `LOGNAME=romil_b sky launch` - underscore
- [x] `LOGNAME=1roMil-b123 sky launch` - number at start gets removed. Becomes `romilb123`
- [x] `LOGNAME=r#omIl_B sky launch`

title: [Catalog] Better handling for catalog fetch failure
body:
Closes #1522.

Before (if you didn't have access to `raw.githubusercontent.com`):
```
$ sky launch
⠸ Updating AWS catalog (every 7 hours)E 12-15 08:17:57 common.py:107] Failed to download AWS catalog:
INTERNALERROR> Traceback (most recent call last):
INTERNALERROR> ConnectionRefusedError: [Errno 111] Connection refused
```

Now (if there's cached catalogs):
```
$ sky launch
⠏ Updating AWS catalog (aws/vms.csv) (every 7 hours)
W 12-16 10:35:01 common.py:114] Failed to fetch AWS catalog (aws/vms.csv). Using cached catalog files.
⠧ Updating AWS catalog (aws/images.csv) (every 7 hours)
W 12-16 10:35:42 common.py:114] Failed to fetch AWS catalog (aws/images.csv). Using cached catalog files.
I 12-16 10:35:42 optimizer.py:606] == Optimizer ==
I 12-16 10:35:42 optimizer.py:618] Target: minimizing cost
```

Now (if there are no cached catalogs):
```
$ sky launch
E 12-16 10:50:53 common.py:119] Failed to fetch AWS catalog (aws/vms.csv). Please check your internet connection.
```


## Tested

`sky launch` under following conditions:

|                           | catalog/v5/aws exists | catalog/v5/aws does not exist |
|---------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------------------|
| raw.github accessible     | Y                     | Y                             |
| raw.github not accessible | Y                     | Y                             |

Also tested removing `catalog/v5/.meta` and editing the catalog.

title: [Catalog] SkyPilot fails to fetch catalogs if raw.githubusercontent.com is blocked
body:
One of the largest ISPs in India, Reliance Jio, blocks `raw.githubusercontent.com`. Regular `github.com` is accessible. This causes SkyPilot catalog download to fail:
```
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments$ pytest test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials
⠸ Updating AWS catalog (every 7 hours)E 12-15 08:17:57 common.py:107] Failed to download AWS catalog:
INTERNALERROR> Traceback (most recent call last):
INTERNALERROR> ConnectionRefusedError: [Errno 111] Connection refused
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> Traceback (most recent call last):
INTERNALERROR> urllib3.exceptions.NewConnectionError: <urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7f6e364a6d10>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 11
1] Connection refused
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> Traceback (most recent call last):
ypilot-catalog/master/catalogs/v5/aws/vms.csv (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7f6e364a6d10>: Failed to establish a ne
w connection: [Errno 111] Connection refused'))
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> Traceback (most recent call last):
INTERNALERROR> FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tmpmatdz6y_' -> '/home/romilb/.sky/catalogs/v5/aws/az_mappings.csv'
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments$ sky check
Checking credentials to enable clouds for SkyPilot.
⠋ Updating AWS catalog (every 7 hours)E 12-15 08:20:17 common.py:107] Failed to download AWS catalog:
ConnectionRefusedError: [Errno 111] Connection refused

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

urllib3.exceptions.NewConnectionError: <urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7fe49e440410>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 111] Connection r
efused

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='raw.githubusercontent.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/mas
ter/catalogs/v5/aws/vms.csv (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7fe49e440410>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Err
no 111] Connection refused'))

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

requests.exceptions.ConnectionError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='raw.githubusercontent.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/
master/catalogs/v5/aws/vms.csv (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7fe49e440410>: Failed to establish a new connection: [
Errno 111] Connection refused'))
```

A simple workaround is to git pull and manually copy over the catalog:
```
git clone https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/
cp -R skypilot-catalog/catalogs/* ~/.sky/catalogs/
```

Now because this does not update the md5 checksum file like we do in our code...:
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/457b88ca79d3495b0ba657a4deecec46cb5f647b/sky/clouds/service_catalog/common.py#L110-L115

... after 7 hours I must again manually update the catalog else SkyPilot tries and fails.

We could either:

1. Make the catalog fetch failure a warning if the catalog already exists locally (graceful fallback to existing catalog)
2. Allow user to configure the catalog update frequency, so they can set it to 0 and not worry about this happening.

Leaning towards 1.

title: Add user identity to cluster status to avoid leakage when switching account
body: Describe the changes in this PR: With #1489, when a user switches account, `sky status -r` will remove the previously launched cluster from the table due to the cluster cannot be found in the new account, causing resource leakage. It could happen whenever user switches account on any cloud. This is to get rid of the problem. --- IMPORTANT: A user with multiple identities for a cloud need to do the following things after upgrading to this PR: 1. Switch to the account used for launching the clusters in the cluster table 2. `sky status -r` so that the owner information can be correctly updated in our cluster table cache. A normal user will not be affected by the PR. --- Tested (run the relevant ones): - [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud aws`; switch to another account; `sky status -r` - [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud aws`; switch to another account; `sky launch -c min`; `sky down min`; `sky stop min`; `sky start min` - [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud gcp`; switch to another account; `sky status -r` - [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud azure`; switch to another account; `sky status -r` - [x] `./tests/run_smoke_tests.sh` (except for TPU VM tests #1500 and list source files #1510). - [x] `./tests/backward_compatibility.sh`

title: [AWS] Bring-your-own-VPC that disables public IPs for all SkyPilot nodes.
body:
Support bring-your-own-VPC that disables public IPs for all SkyPilot nodes (incl. spot controller).

Introduces an experimental `sky_config` module that reads `~/.sky/config.yaml`, a YAML config file for such networking/auth settings. See below for an example config.

NOTEs
- Any existing clusters will _not_ pick up new configs, even if those clusters are stopped and then restarted
- **Configs are tied to the lifetime of each cluster**: configs are read once when a new cluster is launched and immutable after
  - i.e., if a cluster X was launched with config C, and later some changes to the config were made, restarting cluster X would work and it would still use the original config

## Steps to set up a new VPC (single region) to test this PR
- Provision a new VPC
  - Example: Use https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/vpc/home?region=us-east-1#CreateVpc:createMode=vpcWithResources
    - Give it a unique name, e.g., "sky", "skypilot"
    - For NAT gateways, select “1 per AZ”
  - or use some other tool (e.g., Terraform)
- Provision a jump server VM
  - Ensure local client can ssh into jump server
  - Ensure jump server can ping the newly created VPC using private IP
  - Both of the above are satisfied by: 
    - Manually launch a `t2.micro` VM in a "public" subnet of the new VPC; select `sky-key` as keypair; make sure to choose assign public IP
- Switch to a new `~/.sky` environment: for example, `cp -r` that dir somewhere, and remove `~/.sky/*`.
  - Things will still work without this step, but this will make testing easier
- Add a config file at `~/.sky/config.yaml`. Example:
```yaml
aws:
  # The VPC to use in each region.
  #
  # If this is set, any region without a unique VPC with this name will not be
  # able to launch SkyPilot nodes. SkyPilot's failover will still properly
  # function to look for such an eligible region.
  #
  # Optional; default: None (SkyPilot will use the default VPC in each region).
  vpc_name: skypilot-vpc

  # Set to true to use private IPs to communicate between the local client and
  # any SkyPilot nodes. This requires the networking stack is properly set up.
  # Specifically, setting this flag means SkyPilot will only use subnets that
  # satisfy both of the following to launch nodes:
  #  - subnets with name tags containing the substring "private"
  #  - subnets that are configured to not assign public IPs (the
  #    `map_public_ip_on_launch` attribute is False)
  #
  # This flag is typically set together with 'vpc_name' above and
  # 'auth.ssh_proxy_command'.
  #
  # Optional; default: False.
  use_internal_ips: True

auth:
  # If set, this is passed as the '-o ProxyCommand' option for any SSH
  # connections (including rsync) used to communicate between the local client
  # and any SkyPilot nodes. This option is not used between SkyPilot nodes,
  # since they may not have such a proxy set up.
  #
  # Useful for using a jump server to communicate with SkyPilot nodes hosted in
  # private subnets without public IPs.
  #
  # Optional; default: None.
  ssh_proxy_command: ssh -W %h:%p -i ~/.ssh/sky-key -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no ec2-user@xxxxxx
```
  - Be sure to replace `vpc_name` with the newly created VPC name; and in `ssh_proxy_command` replace `<user>@<jump server public IP>`. (Alternatively, use your own proxy setup there.)

## Steps to set up VPC peering between 2 regions
- Use the above two create 2 VPCs in 2 regions; **use the same name**
- Create a VPC Peering Connection
  - Requires: the two VPCs should have non-overlapping CIDR ranges (e.g., 10.0.0.0/16, 10.1.0.0/16, ...)
    - These are specified at VPC creation, and thus requires "network/IP address range planning"
- Modify the route tables of each VPC
  - Inside VPC 1's each route table, add a route: (Destination=CIDR of the other VPC, e.g., 10.1.0.0/16; Target=pcx-xxxxxx (the peering connection ID))
  - Inside VPC 2's each route table, add a route: (Destination=CIDR of the other VPC, e.g., 10.0.0.0/16; Target=pcx-xxxxxx (the peering connection ID))
  - Do this for all route tables, including the single public route table + per-AZ private route tables in each VPC
  - NOTE
    - Technically, only need one direction for "jump server VPC -> sky vpc" (i.e., the above needs only be done for jump server VPC)
    - But between 2 sky VPCs, do both directions (since spot controller can be in any region).

More info on peering
- Follow the first 5 steps, up to and including 'Update route tables', in https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/peering/working-with-vpc-peering.html
- Easier to follow tutorial: https://dev.to/aws-builders/a-simple-vpc-peering-tutorial-48mo
  - (no need to do the security group step at the end)


## Deferred for the future
- [ ] (deferred) per-region proxy command
- [ ] have a simple preflight test for proxy command
- [ ] (deferred) make Python API pick up configs easier 


## Testing

**TODOs**
- [x] smoke tests
- [x] remove some `logger.info`


<!-- Describe tests ran in a "Tested:" section -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of Github CI; the below are additional tests. -->

**Tested**:

- [x] failover cross-region
- [x] spot launch with region migration
- [x] Ran the following, with the above single-region setup:
  - autostop
  - launch
  - exec
  - queue
  - logs
  - status -r
  - ssh clus
  - spot *
- [X] cross-region with peering setup: sky spot launch ‘echo $(hostname)’
  - VPC 1: us-east-1
    - jump server
    - spot controller
  - VPC 2: us-west-2
    - data plane
- [X] cross-region with peering setup:
  - VPC 1: us-east-1
    - jump server
  - VPC 2: us-west-2
    - data plane
- [x] All smoke tests, without any config: `bash tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`  (e82c4b461657988)
- [x] All smoke tests, with the above config and setup: `bash tests/run_smoke_tests.sh` (e82c4b461657988)
  - This requires setting up (1) 4 VPCs in 4 AWS US regions (2) peering connections between them
  - All passed, except for `TestStorageWithCredentials::test_bucket_bulk_deletion[StoreType.GCS]` being flaky (1-2 times out of ~5 times pass rate), unrelated?
- [x] Backward compatibility tests, without any config: `bash tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh` (commit e82c4b461657988)
- [x] Backward compatibility tests, with the above config and setup: `bash tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh` (commit e82c4b461657988)

title: [Autostop] Need to reset the timer for every execution stage
body:
Our user observed that the spot controller is autostopped, during the submission of a spot job (during setting up the controller). It is possible because we only reset the autostop timer, when the controller process is submitted to the ray job.

One way to mitigate it is to reset the autostop timer at the beginning of every execution stage. cc @concretevitamin

title: [Storage] Uploading list of files to bucket fails
body:
Seems the following test failed, after this #1494, cc @infwinston:
```
_________________________________________________________________________________________________ TestStorageWithCredentials.test_list_source[StoreType.S3] __________________________________________________________________________________________________
[gw0] linux -- Python 3.10.6 /home/ubuntu/.conda/envs/sky/bin/python3.1
tests/test_smoke.py:1361: in test_list_source
    tmp_local_list_storage_obj.add_store(store_type)
sky/data/storage.py:658: in add_store
    self._sync_store(store)
sky/data/storage.py:725: in _sync_store
    os.path.join(self.source, '.git')):
../.conda/envs/sky/lib/python3.10/posixpath.py:76: in join
    a = os.fspath(a)
E   TypeError: expected str, bytes or os.PathLike object, not list
```

I believe the reason is that we did not take the `self.source` to be a list into account in the following place. https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/742c1dc82e62322d4e6d61c68b021b816f6110ad/sky/data/storage.py#L723-L728

title: [sqlite] Mitigate the database locked problem for skylet config
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

This PR is to mitigate the problem in #1507

Enable the WAL mode for the database we are using for autostop to eliminate the undesired locking.

After this PR, the snippet in #1507 fails 1/30, while it fails 30/30 when using the current master branch.

```
import time
from multiprocessing.pool import Pool

def import_skylet_config(i):
    from sky.skylet import configs
    print('Process', i)
    configs.set_config('autostop_last_active_time', str(time.time()))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    cnt = 0
    total = 30
    for i in range(total):
        try:
            with Pool(100) as p:
                p.map(import_skylet_config, range(10000))
        except Exception as e:
            print(e)
            cnt += 1
    print('Failed', cnt, 'times out of', total)
```

Future TODO:
- [ ] Adopt the WAL mode to all the database we are using?

title: [AWS Catalog] Handle the exceptions when the user does not have access to the region
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Describe the changes in this PR:

Fixes #1459 

Our previous `fetch_availability_zone_mappings` does not handle the case where the user does not have access to some of the regions, causing the problem in #1459, where the @iojw fails to fetch his own mapping.

**The previous problem could affect all the AWS users without the `ap-east-1` access.**

It also adds the integrity check to make sure that the auto-update of the catalog will always fetch all the regions.


<!-- Describe tests ran in a "Tested:" section -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of Github CI; the below are additional tests. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] `python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_aws --strict-all-regions`
- [x] `python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_aws` using an account without access to all regions
- [x] `sky launch -c test-mapping --cloud aws` on an account without access to all regions
- [x] @iojw, could you test with this PR to see if this will correctly generate the `az_mapping` for your account?

title: docs: How do I launch 100 jobs?
body:
User asked

> Q: if i want to launch 100 jobs w/ auto termination, what do i do

---

I parsed this question as:
- what command(s) do I run? 
- `sky launch` 100 times? 
- or `sky launch -c` once and `sky exec` 100 times? (or other jobs : clusters distribution?) 
- or `sky spot launch` 100 times?

We should provide a user guide on this. This probably belongs to the "Job Queue" page, or potentially a standalone page under the Running Jobs section.

title: docs: Clarify autostop/autodown logic is on the cluster, not laptop
body:
User asked this question:

> Q: autostop - can i close my laptop? is logic on cloud or laptop

We should make it very clear in docs.

body:

#1190 introduced a bug for downloading the logs from the remote cluster, as we are giving the `runner.rsync` the wrong source path (resolved the path locally, though it is a remote path). This PR fixes the issue.

Reproducible code:

```
sky launch -i10 -c master-branch "echo hi"
sky logs master-branch 1 -s  
```
The downloaded folder does not contain any `run.log`.

title: Create pull_request_template.md
body: This basic template ensures tests are run and documented, while requiring minimal effort to fill in.

title: Add safe guard for provisioning/terminating TPU VM and fix spot launch TPU resource leak
body:
Our user reported some errors when getting TPU IPs. This PR adds some safe guard for `_get_tpu_vm_pod_ips` with better error handling to prevent failures like leaked resources with duplicated cluster IDs.

This PR also fixed https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1514 which tried to remove an `INIT` TPU VM resource.

Tested:
- [x] launching TPU VM/TPU Pod
- [x] TPU Pod smoke test

title: [AWS] Enable requested ap regions
body: Previously, the `ap-east-1` region was disabled in our automatically updated catalog as it is not enabled by default on AWS. However, one of our users is trying to restart a cluster in that region.

title: [AWS] Add regions requested by the user
body: Our user requested to use `ap-east-1` region, we now enable this for the user so that the auto-updated catalog works.

title: [Failover] Fix leakage of existing cluster when failed to start
body:
Closes #1496.

Tested:
- The reproducible snippets in the #1496 
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: [Failover] The stopped cluster will be removed from the cluster table if failed to restart
body:
There is a leakage of the STOPPED cluster if the user tries to `sky start` the cluster and failed due to no resources.

Reproducible snippets:
1. Run the following commands
```
sky launch -c test-ap --cloud --region ap-east-1 -y
sky stop test-ap
```
2. Remove the ap-east-1 region from the `aws/vms.csv`
3. `sky start test-ap`, the restart fails as expected, but the cluster is removed from the table as well. which causes the leakage of the stopped resources.

Reason: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/655267b005a22173750dacd588d2249397bec060/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1922-L1923

title: [Tests] Fix github CI
body:
This fixes the GitHub CI, because the GitHub runner recently updated the OS used by `ubuntu-latest` to `ubuntu-22.04`, which does not support python 3.6 anymore, as mentioned in https://github.com/actions/runner-images/issues/6399.
https://github.blog/changelog/2022-12-01-github-actions-larger-runners-using-ubuntu-latest-label-will-now-use-ubuntu-22-04/

PS, we may also want to consider deprecating the Python 3.6 support #609 

This PR separates the CI fix from #1493 and #1489. 

Tested:
- the github CI is green now.

title: Exclude .git for cloud storage
body:
This is a quick patch to make s3 exclude `.git` for https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1485. However, this might be a surprising behavior to some users.
Alternative is to implement our own code to read `.gitignore` and generate corresponding directories to exclude (i.e., parsing those `**/*.pyc` syntax ourselves)
Should we implement that?

Note `sky launch` will respect `.gitignore` and putting `.git/` inside is enough to exclude the directory. or should we make it default for all `rsync`?

Tested
- [x] `sky spot launch` a workdir containing `.git`
- [x] mounted storage with S3, GCS

title: [Spot] Add option for specifying controller instance type
body:
Adding an advance option to specify spot controller instance type, so that user can specify a smaller controller if they need it. Also, this unblocks the testing for the SSO login in #1489, to use a free tier spot controller.

Tested:
- [x] `sky spot launch --controller-type m6i.large echo hi`

title: Catalog: sort by (price, region name, zone name).
body:
A few revisions ago the first region for the default AWS VM is `us-east-1`. After updating I noticed the first region becomes `us-west-2`. Both have the same on-demand price 0.384 for m6i.2xlarge. This is not a bug, but is a bit surprising to see, and it may require opening the console in a new region for debugging work.

This PR changes the sorting algorithm to sort by (price, region name, zone name) so that the same-priced regions can break ties consistently.

title: [AWS SSO] Use service account to access EC2 and S3 on head and worker nodes
body: This partially fixes #1488 For aws, we now set the worker nodes to have the same IAM role as the head node, so that they can correctly access s3 buckets without the need to upload the user's credential files (TBD: using the same role will allow the worker to access EC2 as well, which may not be necessary, and we can fix it by creating a new s3-access role for that, such as `skypilot-service-worker-v1`). Having the `IAM:PassRole` for the IAM role is required, as the head node has to pass the role `skypilot-service-v1` to the worker node. It also adds mypy check for `sky/clouds/*.py` TODO: - [x] Backward compatibility test, as the service account name has been changed. - [x] Without uploading the credential files to the VM, the spot controller launched on other clouds will not be able to create instance on AWS. [We added back credential uploads, as the VMs on other clouds needs that to access AWS] For an SSO account, we will show the following hints: Tested: - [x] `sky launch -c multi-node -t t3.micro ./examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` with a private s3 bucket. - [x] `sky launch -c multi-node-sso -t t3.micro ./examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` with a private s3 bucket, using an account set up with SSO and `AdministratorAccess` - [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh` - [x] `tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh` - [x] `sky launch -t t2.micro -i 0`; `sky status -r` correctly autostopped with SSO account. - [x] According to our user, the current PR works with their SSO account.

title: [IAM] Utilize ray-autoscaler-v1 IAM role on the remote VM
body:
Instead of using user's credentials on the remote VM, we need to utilize the `ray-autoscaler-v1` to handle the autostop/autodown and make the spot controller able to operate the clusters.
This will benefits:
1. better security for not copying the user's credentials.
2. it will unblock the users using SSO login, with which the user's credential can be expired.

title: [request] Support exposing a port from a Skypilot VM
body:
SSH forwarding is the only supported way to expose a port to the world in Skypilot [today](https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/gpu-jupyter.html). However, I need public access to the VM without SSH forwarding.

The task YAML should support a ports field:
```
ports:
  - 8080
```

I currently must manually add the port via the AWS EC2 console.

title: [Spot] Make non-terminal spot job status more clear when the table is from the cache
body:
It can be confusing to see the job in non-terminal status when the `sky spot queue` returns the cached table. From our user:
> Also the user experience of
```
Spot controller sky-spot-controller-39f73709 is STOPPED.
To view the latest job table: sky spot queue --refresh

Cached job status table [last updated: 20 hrs ago]:
```
> is a bit confusing, especially when I have many historical spot jobs in the queue. It’s not always immediately clear whether it’s displaying historical status or latest and I have to explicitly look for this earlier small blob of text.
Maybe make it appear to the bottom of the content rather than to the top (or both) would help..

We can replace the non-terminal spot job status with `NEED REFRESH` to avoid confusion.

title: [Storage] Workdir sync to S3 is too slow (not respecting `.gitignore`; syncing a giant `.git` dir)
body:
User reported workdir sync to s3 (used by managed spot, `sky spot launch`) is too slow:
- not respecting .gitignore
- syncing a giant .git dir

This caused the user to use GitHub cloning/pushing as an alternative and abandon using the workdir feature.

---

Quotes:
> Is there a way to ignore the .git folder itself when syncing code via workdir? Reason is that it’s too large. Actually I suspect the main slowness is not size, but that there are many files in .git. ... Would it make sense to upload a zipped file instead of syncing file-by-file?

> It also seems that the sync to s3 is not respecting .gitignore. for now I think I will have to bypass the workdir feature and sync code some other way since it’s too slow to upload to s3 for me

> (network bandwidth is not the issue; it’s the number of files needed to sync, & aws s3 sync is much less efficient than rsync)

We suggested using mounted storage and user said: 
> I think I’ll just git clone for now

title: [Test] spot smoke test failures due to controller INIT state
body:
I've been encountering many smoke tests failures recently but not because bugs in the code. Many are related to failures of getting the latest spot status due to controller state to be `INIT`. This is likely due to other ongoing `spot launch` which modified the controller state.

```
Fetching managed spot job statuses...
D 12-02 00:23:55 backend_utils.py:1732] Refreshing status: Failed get the lock for cluster 'sky-spot-controller-4da3f903'. Using the cached status.
Spot controller sky-spot-controller-4da3f903 is INIT.
Please wait for the controller to be ready.
....
Failed
``` 

I think we should treat this as a smoke test bug? or is it just me having this issue?
To fix it we may need to make `spot queue` more robust.

title: Clean up preempted resources for TPU
body:
This PR implements a better fix for https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1468.
The preempted VM has to be cleaned up otherwise it'd occupy the quota.

Another choice is to modify the Autoscaler node provider, but I think that might complicate the semantic of `create_node` function. because for normal compute VM, we instead want to keep and reuse the preempted resources.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/1955bee5a337508af67de28615ed03a594fa30cf/sky/skylet/providers/gcp/node_provider.py#L178

Explicitly calling `terminate_cluster` on higher level might be better. @Michaelvll wdyt?
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/1955bee5a337508af67de28615ed03a594fa30cf/sky/spot/recovery_strategy.py#L99

TODO
- [x] Spot related smoke tests
- [x] Test the recovery from real preemption (in progress)

title: [Spot/UX] Need a way to only show the RUNNING spot jobs
body:
Request from our user:
> Is there a way to clear jobs that are finished (either "SUCCEEDED" or "FAILED")?

title: Fix `ResourceHandle` semantics
body:
This fixes the following issues with the new `ResourceHandle` introduced in #1380.

- For clusters from the older version that are in INIT status, `sky status -r` will not update them to the latest version, causing the IPs for these clusters to be queried on each call which is slow. This PR updates it such that these clusters will be updated to the latest version on refresh.
- #1480: fixes the handling of TPU pods 
- ~The `external_ips` and `internal_ips` methods should always return a list as that is what is expected by the rest of the code~

Tested:
- [x] test_tpu_vm_pod

title: [TPU] Can't launch a TPU Pod
body:
Now launching a TPU Pod will trigger below error
```
  File "/Users/weichiang/repos/sky/sky/utils/common_utils.py", line 233, in _record
    return f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/weichiang/repos/sky/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1345, in _gang_schedule_ray_up
    self._tpu_pod_setup(cluster_config_file, cluster_handle)
  File "/Users/weichiang/repos/sky/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1161, in _tpu_pod_setup
    if len(all_ips) != num_tpu_devices:
TypeError: object of type 'NoneType' has no len()
```

This seems to be introduced after https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1380 where 
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/5506e1dec428c8bd6dff4110ea86e6c5e76bd9dd/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L1158
returns an empty list and caused the bug.

@iojw Should the semantic of `handle.external_ips()` always returns a list of IPs?

Also we should probably make TPU Pod's smoke test run by default to avoid such bug.

title: [Spot] Let the controller aware of the failed setup and fail early
body:
Closes #1397 

When the spot job fails during setup, the master branch will retry 3 times (or forever if `--retry-until-up` is specified), and set the spot job to `FAILED_NO_RESOURCES`, which is not desired. 

This PR makes the controller aware of the failure of the setup early, and set the spot job to `FAILED`.

A side benefit: the setup logs will go to `sky spot logs` as well, so the user don't have to use `sky logs sky-spot-controller` too see the output of their job's setup.

Tested:
- [x] `sky spot launch -n test-setup-failure ./tests/test_yamls/failed_setup.yaml`
- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py` (except for #1428)

title: [Global Regions] Add geographical area for task
body:
This is a preview of having geographical area selection in the resources spec. With this PR, we should have our catalog includes the global regions, and this PR defaults the failover to US regions only.

```
resources:
    area: eu # only failover on Europe regions
    # area: all # failover on global regions
```

```
resources:
    # without area defaults to us
```

```
resources:
    region: ap-south-1 # succeed, ignore the default area value
```

```
resources:
    region: ap-south-1
    area: eu # ignore this setting.
```

title: Hotfix for spot TPU pod recovery
body:
A hotfix to temporarily close https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1468. We may need to modify the controller logic to make it more future proof. 

The issue is: When preemption happens, our spot controller won't cleanup preempted VMs before running another `sky launch`. This causes two VMs to co-exist and both the preempted one and the recovered one will be returned.

title: [AWS] Use the AZ ID instead of AZ name for the price
body:
As discovered by @WoosukKwon, the AZ name can correspond to different AZ ID for different accounts. We should use the AZ ID for the catalog of AWS and have a mapping from AZ ID -> AZ name for the user.

> To ensure that resources are distributed across the Availability Zones for a Region, we independently map Availability Zones to codes for each AWS account. For example, the Availability Zone us-east-1a for your AWS account might not be the same physical location as us-east-1a for another AWS account.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-regions-availability-zones.html

title: No usable subnets matching availability zone
body:
For the `us-west-1` region on AWS, my account only has access to the `us-west-1b` and `us-west-1c` zones, but SkyPilot does not take this into account. This causes the following error when running some of the smoke tests:

```
+ sky status --refresh | grep test-autostop-a64f6128-dd | grep STOPPED
Error: No usable subnets matching availability zone ['us-west-1a'] found for node type ray.head.default.
Choose a different availability zone or try manually creating an instance in your specified region to populate the list of subnets and trying this again.
```

The `aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region region-name` command can determine what zones a user has access to. e.g. for me:

```
❯ aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region us-west-1
{
    "AvailabilityZones": [
        {
            "State": "available",
            "OptInStatus": "opt-in-not-required",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-west-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-west-1b",
            "ZoneId": "usw1-az3",
            "GroupName": "us-west-1",
            "NetworkBorderGroup": "us-west-1",
            "ZoneType": "availability-zone"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "OptInStatus": "opt-in-not-required",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-west-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-west-1c",
            "ZoneId": "usw1-az1",
            "GroupName": "us-west-1",
            "NetworkBorderGroup": "us-west-1",
            "ZoneType": "availability-zone"
        }
    ]
}
```

title: Make `sky start` on the spot controller aware of autostop.
body:
Fixes #1447.

If controller is to be started:
 - disallow: -i, --down; disallow being specified with other clusters

Tested:

CLI
```
# Expectedly fail:
sky start sky-cpunode-zongheng sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2
sky start sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2 -i1
sky start sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2 -i1 --down
sky start sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2 --down

# Starting a stopped controller: OK. Autostop reset to 10m.
sky start sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2  

# Starting an UP controller: OK. Autostop reset to 10m.
sky start sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2 --force 
```
Python API
- [x] repeated the above and observed appropriate ValueError
- [x] manually called `core.start()` on a stopped controller; verfied autostop is set to 10m

Smoke
- [x] `bash tests/run_smoke_tests.sh test_spot`

title: Logging fixes.
body: Fix a few logging UX issues: 1. Previously: ``` » sky spot logs 3 Spot controller sky-spot-controller-8a3968f2 is INIT. Please wait for the controller to be ready. sky.exceptions.ClusterNotUpError ``` This PR removes the last line. 2. Previously, the controller log for a preempted spot job shows: The red text is part of the "Exception" in the line above, but looks weird when joining with `)`. This PR rearranges it a bit. 3. Previously `sky spot status` shows: ``` WARNING: `status` is deprecated and will be removed in a future release. Please use `queue` instead. ``` This may be a bit confusing as to whether it also refers to `sky status`. This PR makes it more clear.

title: [AWS] Update catalog from host periodically
body:
Closes #1437, #1461
This PR simplifies #1449 (removes the config). It will update the local catalog cache periodically (every 7 hours) so that the price can be up-to-date.

It should be merged together with https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/pull/4

Tested:
- [x] run `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Multi-node launching when out-of-quotas will fail over without hinting the reason
body:
User reported:

> I was getting consistent failovers even when launching on-demand instances (g4dn.12xlarge; spot instances launched fine). Curious if the timeout of waiting for worker provisioning might be set to be too short?

> I 11-26 17:42:45 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1249] Launching on AWS us-west-2 (us-west-2d,us-west-2b,us-west-2a,us-west-2c)
I 11-26 17:44:21 log_utils.py:45] Head node is up.
I 11-26 17:45:57 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1356] Successfully provisioned or found existing head VM. Waiting for workers.
E 11-26 17:47:34 backend_utils.py:992] Timed out: waited for more than 90 seconds for new workers to be provisioned, but no progress.
E 11-26 17:47:34 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1118] *** Failed provisioning the cluster. ***
E 11-26 17:47:34 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1120] *** Terminating the failed cluster. ***
I 11-26 17:48:00 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1249] Launching on AWS us-east-2 (us-east-2c,us-east-2b,us-east-2a)
I 11-26 17:49:20 log_utils.py:45] Head node is up.
I 11-26 17:50:40 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1356] Successfully provisioned or found existing head VM. Waiting for workers.
E 11-26 17:52:19 backend_utils.py:992] Timed out: waited for more than 90 seconds for new workers to be provisioned, but no progress.
E 11-26 17:52:19 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1118] *** Failed provisioning the cluster. ***
E 11-26 17:52:19 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1120] *** Terminating the failed cluster. ***
I 11-26 17:52:46 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1249] Launching on AWS us-east-1 (us-east-1f,us-east-1e,us-east-1d,us-east-1c,us-east-1b,us-east-1a)
I 11-26 17:54:11 log_utils.py:45] Head node is up.

Later it was reported that this is due to low vCPU limits:
> It seems that the error was actually caused by my vCPU limit not sufficient to launch additional worker nodes. But the timeout error was kind of obscure.

----

Some things to fix

- [ ] Consider detecting the failures are due to quotas, then print a better message  (currently there isn't a way according to https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1260#issuecomment-1280284189)
- [ ] If we can't easily detect, print quota as a possible reason anyway
